summary:
In a high-stakes Catalonian derby, Espanyol took on Barcelona at their home ground, but it was the visitors who clinched a commanding victory with a scoreline of 2-0. The derby delivered moments of tactical brilliance, individual flair, and moments of contentious refereeing decisions.

The match commenced with Barcelona gaining initial possession, kicking off the game at precisely 00:00. Right from the off, Barcelona established their attacking intent, launching into their first offensive maneuver that resulted in an on-target shot by the 2nd minute (02:02). Despite this early attempt, the ball soon went out of play at 02:06, necessitating a throw-in from Barcelona.

Barcelona refused to relent, mounting another attempt on goal at 05:03 which forced a save from the Espanyol goalkeeper. Subsequent phases included a series of throw-ins and clearances, with Barcelona executing a corner at 05:32 followed by another at 08:23. Espanyol, however, remained resilient in their defensive duties, managing clearances whenever Barcelona threatened. 

At the 7th minute, Espanyol committed a foul, leading to an indirect free-kick for Barcelona, which ultimately went out of play at 07:14. Barcelona continued their attacking onslaught with their intricate passing and off-ball movements. At 11:55, Iniesta’s attempt at a crossfield pass was intercepted, reflecting Espanyol's vigilant defensive play. Barcelona's persistence paid off as Gerard Pique found himself on the wrong end of the referee's whistle at the 13th minute for a bad challenge on an Espanyol player, earning the home side an indirect free-kick.

Espanyol's efforts to push back were apparent but presented in isolated events, their offense continually stymied either by the offside trap or solid defensive clearances from Barcelona. Espanyol's defensive tire was further tested when Neymar broke the deadlock at the 16th minute. Lionel Messi showcased his visionary passing ability with a superbly lofted ball to Jordi Alba, who with extraordinary foresight delivered the assist to Neymar. Neymar, demonstrating his composure, expertly placed the ball into the net from close range to set the score at 0-1 in favor of Barcelona.

The momentum from the visitors continued to mount. Two minutes later, in the 24th minute, Messi capitalized again on some skillful interplay. Receiving a neat ball from Luis Suarez, Messi made space for a low drive and sent the ball into the back of the net off the right post to double Barcelona's lead at 0-2. Espanyol, now reeling, seemed unable to effectively disrupt Barcelona’s rhythm.

The home side attempted to claw their way back into the match, managing their first notable opportunity in the 27th minute, though Felipe Caicedo’s wild shot flew high and wide. Barcelona, despite being two goals up, did not let up, controlling the tempo and field with precise passing, frustrating Espanyol's attempts to mount an effective counterattack. Barcelona's offensive prowess continued to shine, with more efforts on and off target, continuously pressuring Espanyol’s defense and challenging goalkeeper Francisco Casilla.

By half-time, Barcelona held a firm grip over the game with a 2-0 lead, their coherent and methodical approach starkly contrasting with Espanyol's sporadic bursts of initiative.

As the second half began, Espanyol took the kick-off, seeking to overturn their 2-0 deficit. Yet the second half began in similar fashion to the first, with Barcelona dominating possession and Espanyol resorting to fouls in their attempts to regain control. Espanyol committed a foul less than a minute into the restart, giving away an indirect free-kick to Barcelona at the 01:17 mark.

As both sides traded possession, Espanyol attempted to find in-roads into Barcelona’s defense. Felipe Caicedo tried to create opportunities but was often caught offside or hampered by effective Barcelona defending. Victor Alvarez managed two successive corner kicks for Espanyol, but neither yielded a goal as Barcelona's defense remained impenetrable.

Neymar continued to be a relentless threat, coming close to scoring early in the second half at 05:07, although his shot was safely gathered by Casilla. The frequency of fouls increased as both teams sought to wrest control, leading to several indirect free-kicks for Barcelona. Hector Moreno’s overly aggressive challenge on Neymar at the 06:10 minute resulted in another free-kick and emphasized the deteriorating discipline within Espanyol’s ranks.

Tensions rose further when Barcelona’s Jordi Alba, after receiving a yellow card for dissent at the 08:19 mark, was subsequently shown a red card at 09:10 for further dissent, reducing the visitors to ten men. Despite being a man down, Barcelona's command over the game remained evident. Lionel Messi almost found the net again, only for his shot to be deflected onto the post by a defender’s last-ditch effort.

Espanyol's attempts to capitalize on their numerical advantage saw them push forward, but Barcelona’s disciplined defending and Claudio Bravo’s assured goalkeeping ensured that any threats were neutralized. A wave of substitutions followed, as the teams sought fresh legs and tactical adjustments to shift the game’s momentum.

Crucial defensive plays from Barcelona, exemplified by Jeremy Mathieu's solid clearance after his substitution, ensured that Espanyol's attacking efforts did not bear fruit. Luis Suarez, Neymar, and Messi continued to orchestrate Barcelona’s offensive plays, with Neymar missing a notable chance as he directed a shot just over the crossbar after Suarez’s pass.

As the match wore on, Espanyol's frustration was palpable, leading to a yellow card for Lucas at 26:01 and another for Anaitz Arbilla at 16:40 for a rough challenge. Further cautionary cards were dispensed with Espanyol players walking a tightrope of disciplinary action. Yet, they occasionally threatened, Christian Stuani’s strike towards the bottom right corner of Barcelona’s goal at 40:52 was thwarted by Bravo’s impeccable save, denying them a way back into the match.

The game’s latter stages were marked by increasingly desperate fouls from Espanyol, culminating in Hector Moreno's second yellow card for dissent in the dying moments of the match, resulting in his ejection after receiving a red card at 45:52. With the numerical balance restored, Barcelona comfortably saw out the remainder of the match, their defense quelling any last-minute attempts from Espanyol.

The final whistle blew with Barcelona securing a 2-0 victory, a testament to their tactical superiority and individual brilliance despite being reduced to ten men. Throughout the match, minimal but crucial interventions from Claudio Bravo and cohesive defensive performances ensured a clean sheet, accompanying the decisive strikes from Neymar and Messi.

In conclusion, the derby displayed Barcelona’s possession-based football masterclass, punctuated by moments of individual genius and disciplined defensive work. Espanyol's approach, characterized by quick counters and their physical engagement, largely fell short against the technical prowess and organized play of Barcelona, who emerged deserved victors in this fiercely contested fixture.
